description: From Middle Dutch ruter, rutter, variants of ruiter, from Middle French routier (“mercenary soldier”), corresponding to rout +‎ -ier.

entries.meaning: (historical) A horseman or cavalryman, especially a German one, associated with the wars of the 16th and 17th centuries. [from 16th c.]
examples: Such a regiment of rutters / Never defied men braver

description: From Middle French routier, corresponding to route +‎ -ier.

entries.meaning: (historical) A set of instructions for navigating a course at sea; a pilot's book or seaman's guide. [from 16th c.]
examples: But a rutter was only as good as the pilot who write it, the scribe who hand-copied it, the very rare printer who printed it, or the scholar who translated it.

entries.meaning: (now chiefly Scotland) A tool used in peat cutting or for marking off ground. [from 18th c.]
(Canada, US, now historical) A type of plough used by lumberjacks to carve a track for a sleigh. [from 19th c.]

examples: She moved my rutter so that it was not poking into her. We fell asleep.
